summary: This is an email correspondence discussing the 11th Circuit Court's decision in the case 'In re Wild', which held that rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) do not attach until formal criminal proceedings are initiated. The decision is applied to the case of Jeffrey Epstein, noting that because the government never filed charges against him but entered into a non-prosecution agreement, the CVRA was never triggered.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the non-prosecution agreement discussed in the email. The document references the failure to prosecute him and the legal implications regarding the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

events.title: 11th Circuit Decision in In re Wild
events.description: The 11th Circuit Court of Appeals decided that rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) do not attach until criminal proceedings have been initiated against a defendant via complaint, information, or indictment.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The government entered into a non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein without filing formal charges, which, according to the 11th Circuit's decision, meant the CVRA was never triggered.

keyFacts: The 11th Circuit Court ruled in 'In re Wild' that the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) rights only attach after criminal proceedings are formally initiated (by complaint, information, or indictment).
Because the government never filed charges against Jeffrey Epstein and instead entered into a non-prosecution agreement, the CVRA was never triggered in his case.
The document is an email from May 28, 2020, discussing this legal precedent and its application to the Epstein case.
